abstract.p: Readers suggest silly names and ridiculous descriptions for Web sites; top entry is DigitalDivide.com, Web portal for those without Internet access; photo (M)

block.p: IN the March 29 issue of E-Commerce, the writer Sue Cummings described the free-for-all for desirable Web site addresses. She also challenged readers to think up the silliest possible name for a site and invent an equally ridiculous description.

IN the March 29 issue of E-Commerce, the writer Sue Cummings described the free-for-all for desirable Web site addresses. She also challenged readers to think up the silliest possible name for a site and invent an equally ridiculous description.
About 50 entries were received. (Many came in well after April 1, showing perhaps that the paper's readers have the same lack of respect for deadlines as its writers do.)

The winner, George S. Goodman, was chosen by Ms. Cummings. He surpassed her requirements by proposing a site that would not only be silly, but also completely useless. Not surprisingly, someone has already registered the name.
DigitalDivide.com would be a Web portal for those who do not have Internet access.

Submissions by the runners-up spoofed tried-and-true Web formulas. The first runner-up, Robert Kirchherr, proposed a site that would post blather spouted in the presidential campaign: Vacuous.gov, providing ''valuable analysis and insights generated by the presidential campaign.''

Howard Lev, the second runner-up, combined the online auction and bulletin board concepts to propose a site that could solve one of life's most pervasive, if not profound, mysteries: LaundryLost.com, a lost-and-found site for laundry. As Mr. Lev describes it, the site would be a place ''where people can post lost-and-found notices (offering a reward) for those lost socks and other garments that go into a washer or dryer but never come out, and where people can auction their own unmatched socks in hopes that someone else needs them to make a 'loving pair' of argyles.''
Mr. Goodman will receive a $25 gift certificate to The New York Times Online Store.
